title: See Oliver Davies’ account of Eckhart in “Later Medieval Mystics

Iacopone may not be unique among male mystics in using the language of childbirth to speak of mystical union, but his emphasis on generation does break with what Caroline Bynum has described as the Cistercian preference for the nurturing aspect of motherhood. See Caroline Walker Bynum, Jesus as Mother: Studies in the Spirituality of the High Middle Ages
Bynum’s reading remains useful in mapping the differences between the Cistercian tradition and the later affective literature, especially Franciscan, inspired by it

Jacopone da Todi

Moore offers a disturbing complement to Bynum’s account of Jesus as mother in his study of Yahweh as bodybuilder: “So hypermasculine did he become that his body ceased to be merely male, and began to sprout female parts. Far from being assuaged, his insecurities about this masculinity now had something new to feed on—a pair of female breasts”; Stephen D. Moore, God’s Gym: Divine Male Bodies of the Bible
He does so, however, with a more conservative notion of gender complementarity in mind. See Santi, “La mistica di Iacopone da Todi
